quotes.quote: Narayana and Nara, the supreme among men, and the goddess Saraswati—salutations to them. Then only may the victory be proclaimed.
quotes.sanskrit: नारायणं नमस्कृत्य नरं चैव नरोत्तमम्। देवीं सरस्वतीं चैव ततो जयमुदीरयेत्॥
quotes.meaning: This opening verse emphasizes the reverence for divine and human excellence before embarking on any great endeavor, acknowledging the sources of wisdom and strength.
quotes.lore_snippet: Before any great undertaking, wise men first honor the divine and the virtuous. Victory is not merely won by strength, but by the blessings of higher powers and wisdom.

quotes.quote: In the beginning, there was the One—the eternal Brahman, manifest and unmanifest, beyond existence and non-existence, the source of all creation.
quotes.sanskrit: आद्यं पुरुषमीशानं... ऋतमेकाक्षरं ब्रह्म व्यक्ताव्यक्तं सनातनम्। असच्च सच्चैव च यद्विश्वं सदसतः परम्॥
quotes.meaning: This verse describes the primordial, indescribable reality (Brahman) that transcends dualities and is the ultimate cause of the universe.
quotes.lore_snippet: The sages speak of a time before time, when only the One existed—neither being nor non-being, yet the seed of all that is. Such is the nature of the Absolute.

quotes.quote: The great knowledge of this epic is established in all three worlds, adorned with divine and human wisdom, and cherished by the learned.
quotes.sanskrit: इदं तु त्रिषु लोकेषु महज्ज्ञानं प्रतिष्ठितम्... विदुषां प्रियम्॥
quotes.meaning: The Mahabharata is revered as a universal scripture, containing profound truths accessible to both gods and mortals.
quotes.lore_snippet: Like a tree whose roots reach the heavens and whose branches shelter the earth, the Mahabharata spans all realms of knowledge, offering wisdom to gods and men alike.

quotes.quote: The world is born and dissolved again like the cycles of seasons, witnessed by all beings in their endless turns.
quotes.sanskrit: यथर्तावृतुलिङ्गानि नानारूपाणि पर्यये दृश्यन्ते तानि तान्येव तथा भावा युगादिषु
quotes.meaning: This verse describes the eternal cycle of creation and destruction, comparing it to the changing seasons—each phase recurring predictably yet taking varied forms.
quotes.lore_snippet: Just as winter’s barrenness yields to spring’s bloom, so too do all things rise and fall in time. The wise see this wheel of existence and act without attachment.

quotes.quote: Vyasa: Knowledge expands when shared, like a flame that lights countless lamps without diminishing itself.
quotes.meaning: Sage Vyasa compressed vast wisdom into the Mahabharata, showing that true knowledge grows when disseminated.
quotes.lore_snippet: The sages teach that wisdom, unlike treasure, multiplies when given freely. A single torch can banish darkness for thousands—so too does enlightenment spread.

quotes.quote: Dhritarashtra’s blindness was not of eyes but of wisdom; roots feed the tree, yet his choices nurtured only poison.
quotes.meaning: Dhritarashtra’s lack of discernment (symbolized by his literal blindness) allowed his sons’ wickedness to flourish, dooming his lineage.
quotes.lore_snippet: A ruler’s duty is to prune vice like a gardener. When the roots embrace rot, even the mightiest tree will fall—and crush the unwise beneath it.

quotes.quote: Dhritarashtra: I see no difference between my sons and Pandu's sons. Yet, my blind affection leads me to tolerate Duryodhana's madness.
quotes.sanskrit: न मे विशेषः पुत्रेषु स्वेषु पाण्डुसुतेषु च
quotes.meaning: Dhritarashtra acknowledges his impartiality in principle, but admits his inability to act justly due to paternal attachment—a confession of weakness in governance.
quotes.lore_snippet: Even kings gifted with divine sight may stumble when family bonds cloud judgment. The wise warn that unchecked favoritism erodes dharma faster than any enemy's blade.

quotes.quote: When the Pandavas entered, flowers rained, conches sounded, and joy arose in all hearts—proving righteousness shines brighter than royal silks.
quotes.meaning: Nature itself celebrated the Pandavas' virtuous return, contrasting their humble exile with Duryodhana's hollow opulence.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient scrolls speak of how the cosmos rejoices when noble souls walk among mortals. Petals fall unbidden, and sacred winds carry their scent to the gods.

quotes.quote: Arjuna obtained divine weapons not by birthright, but by pleasing Shiva through trial—no boon comes without tapasya.
quotes.meaning: Even the mightiest warrior had to earn divine arms through austerity and skill, not inheritance.
quotes.lore_snippet: The Pashupatastra was not gifted—it was won in single combat against the Destroyer himself. This truth humbles princes: divinity favors the disciplined, not the entitled.

quotes.quote: Dhritarashtra: I see not even the slightest benefit in continuing to live.
quotes.sanskrit: स्तोकं ह्यपि न पश्यामि फलं जीवितधारणे
quotes.meaning: A despairing king expresses the futility of clinging to life when overwhelmed by grief and loss.
quotes.lore_snippet: Even the mightiest rulers may find their spirit broken by time's cruel march. Yet as the sages teach: 'Kala (Time) cooks all beings in his cauldron—no sorrow lasts forever.'

quotes.quote: Sanjaya: Time cooks all beings in his cauldron, Time extinguishes them again.
quotes.sanskrit: कालः पचति भूतानि कालः संहरति प्रजाः
quotes.meaning: The immutable law of Time as the ultimate force that creates, sustains, and destroys all existence.
quotes.lore_snippet: The wheel of Kala grinds kings and beggars alike to dust. Warriors who understand this truth fight not for permanence, but for the righteousness of the moment.

quotes.quote: Even those born with divine weapons and splendor equal to Indra succumbed to Time's power.
quotes.meaning: No mortal—regardless of prowess or divine gifts—escapes the inevitable dissolution wrought by Time.
quotes.lore_snippet: Legends speak of radiant kings who could level mountains with celestial arrows. Where are their thrones now? Only their deeds echo in the halls of memory.

quotes.quote: The sages: He who studies this sacred Bharata with devotion is freed from all sins, as butter is churned from curd, as the Brahmana is supreme among men.
quotes.meaning: The study of the Mahabharata with sincere devotion has the power to purify one's soul from all sins, just as the purest essence (butter) emerges from churning.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient scrolls tell us that wisdom purifies like fire purifies gold. Those who contemplate the Bharata's truths with reverence find their karmic burdens lightened, as dawn dispels darkness.
